content.text: *Scientists study undersea methane-eating bacteria for climate mitigation*

New reporting highlights undersea microbes that consume methane bubbling from the ocean floor and explores whether their natural appetite could be harnessed to limit greenhouse gas emissions. Researchers describe how these microbial communities intercept methane at cold seeps, while noting both the promise and practical hurdles of turning them into a climate tool. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, so any safe way to curb releases would be meaningful for warming.
*NASA's Juno mission status unclear amid U.S. shutdown*

NASA's Juno spacecraft orbiting Jupiter may have reached the end of its mission, but its status cannot be confirmed at this time. The uncertainty stems from a U.S. government shutdown that began the same day Juno's latest mission extension expired, leaving the mission in administrative limbo.
*Ancient viral DNA may spark early human development*

New research reported by ScienceAlert suggests that fragments of ancient viral DNA embedded in our genomes may act as “firestarters,” helping to switch on the earliest genetic programs of human life. The work adds to growing evidence that relics of long-ago infections can be repurposed by human cells for essential roles in early development.
*Scientists study Doug Whitney to inform Alzheimer’s prevention*

Scientists are investigating Doug Whitney, who was expected to develop Alzheimer’s decades ago but has not, to uncover biological factors that might protect against dementia and inform prevention or treatment strategies. In parallel, a New Scientist feature examines how inherited risk and lifestyle choices interact, exploring what current evidence can (and cannot) tell individuals about their personal Alzheimer’s risk.
*Geoarchaeologists date Egypt's Karnak Temple to Old Kingdom*

An international team reports that Egypt’s Karnak Temple complex shows evidence of earliest occupation and construction dating to the Old Kingdom (circa 2591–2152 BCE), based on analysis of ceramics and 61 sediment cores published October 6 in Antiquity. The geoarchaeological work also indicates the site rose as a sacred island amid Nile floods and may have been placed to echo a creation myth of first land emerging from primeval waters. Together, the findings trace Karnak’s environmental and cultural transformation across roughly 3,000 years.
*Australian insurers report $4.5bn extreme weather costs, triple 1990s*

Australia’s peak insurance body says extreme weather now costs about $4.5bn a year—around three times 1990s levels—driven by floods, bushfires and storms. The Insurance Council of Australia’s report links rising costs to the climate crisis, ageing infrastructure and population growth in risk‑prone regions, with poorer communities disproportionately affected. A climate risk expert warned insured costs are likely to continue rising.
*Researchers turn ocean CO2 into biodegradable plastic using microbes*

International researchers built a renewable-powered system that captures dissolved CO2 from seawater, converts it into an acid, and feeds it to modified bacteria that produce a compound used to make biodegradable plastics. The team says the platform could be adapted to make chemicals for food, drugs, and fuel in a carbon-negative way.
*Pacific heat waves disrupt ocean carbon sink, study finds*

A new study of the northeastern Pacific off Alaska reports that two prolonged marine heat waves — from 2013 to 2015 and from 2019 to 2020 — altered phytoplankton and zooplankton communities, reducing the downward transport of carbon to the deep ocean. Coverage notes these heat-driven shifts can ripple through food webs and weaken the ocean’s role in regulating the carbon cycle.
*First 2025 harvest supermoon rises tonight; watch live*

The first supermoon of 2025 — the Harvest Moon — peaks tonight, Oct. 6, and will rise around sunset in the evening sky. A free livestream from the Virtual Telescope Project will showcase the view over the Italian countryside for anyone who can’t step outside or has cloudy skies. At its closest point to Earth, the moon can appear up to 14% larger and 30% brighter than at its farthest point.
*Nobel physics prize goes to Clarke, Devoret and Martinis*

The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded Tuesday to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis for "the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunnelling and energy quantisation in an electric circuit". The committee recognized experiments showing quantum effects on large scales within electrical circuits, highlighting how quantum behavior can manifest beyond single particles.
*Engineering study finds Shackleton’s Endurance had preexisting flaws*

A new analysis combining structural engineering with Ernest Shackleton’s diaries and correspondence concludes the Antarctic ship Endurance had multiple design weaknesses and that Shackleton knew it wasn’t the strongest vessel before departing in 1914–15. The research challenges the long-held idea that a rudder problem sealed the ship’s fate, instead pointing to broader structural deficiencies and a design not suited to compressive pack ice loads that ultimately crushed the vessel in 1915. The work, published in Polar Record and informed by insights from the 2022 Endurance22 wreck discovery, reframes how and why the famed ship sank.
*Nobel in medicine honors immune tolerance discoveries*

The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to Mary E. Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell and Shimon Sakaguchi for discoveries explaining how the body prevents immune attacks on its own tissues, known as peripheral immune tolerance. Their work, including identifying regulatory T cells that rein in harmful immune responses, underpins new approaches to autoimmune disease treatment and improving organ transplant outcomes. In a cheerful twist, Ramsdell initially missed the news because he was hiking off the grid and learned of the prize hours later.
